metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: 1km/5day compositing Fraction Vegetation Cover (FVC) product of Heihe River Basin (2015)
metadata.description: The 1 km / 5-day FVC data set of Heihe River basin provides the 5-day FVC synthesis results in 2015. The data uses the data of Terra / MODIS, Aqua / MODIS, and domestic satellites fy3a / MERSI and fy3b / MERSI to build a multi-source remote sensing data set with a spatial resolution of 1 km and a time resolution of 5 days. The whole country is divided into different vegetation divisions and land types, and the conversion coefficient of NDVI and FVC is calculated respectively. The conversion coefficient look-up table and 1km / 5-day synthetic NDVI product production area 1km / 5-day synthetic FVC product are used. In the Heihe River Basin, 1 km / 5-day synthetic FVC products can directly obtain vegetation coverage ratio through high-resolution data to reduce the impact of low-resolution data heterogeneity; in addition, select the typical period of vegetation growth and change, obtain the corresponding growth curve parameters of each pixel by fitting the vegetation index of each pixel time series; and then cooperate with land use map and vegetation classification map, To find the representative uniform pixel of the region to train the conversion coefficient of vegetation index. Compared with the results of high-resolution aster reference FVC in Heihe River Basin, the first step is to aggregate the aster products in Heihe River basin to 1km scale by combining the measured ground data and using the scale up method, and to obtain the aster aggregate FVC data, which is based on spot vegetation remote sensing data released by geoland 2 project (geov1 for short) The results show that the results of geov1 are higher than those of ASTER image combined with ground measurement, and the results of 1 km / 5-day synthetic FVC products in Heihe River Basin are between the two, and the results of 1 km / 5-day synthetic FVC products in Heihe River Basin in the experimental area are better than those of geov1 products. In a word, the comprehensive utilization of multi-source remote sensing data to improve the estimation accuracy and time resolution of FVC parameter products can better serve the application of remote sensing data products.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Fractional Vegetation Cover (FVC) is an essential biophysical parameter in Soil-Vegetation-Atmosphere Transfer (SVAT) schemes to simulate the exchanges between the surface and the atmospheric boundary layer. It characterizes the fraction of vegetation on a flat background covered by vegetation, thereby accounting for the amount of vegetation distributed in a horizontal perspective. For such, an accurate assessment of FVC is mandatory for a thorough description of land surface processes in the surface parameterization schemes implemented in the climate and weather forecasting models. Besides, the FVC is relevant for a wide range of Land Biosphere Applications such as agriculture and forestry, environmental management and land use, hydrology, natural hazards monitoring and management, vegetation-soil dynamics monitoring, drought conditions and fire scar extent. Two main approaches exist to estimate FVC and other bio-physical parameter like Leaf Area Index (LAI). The first one is based upon empirical relationships with vegetation indices, such as the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). The second one relies on radiative transfer models inverted by neural network or look-up tables. The scattering, absorption and reflection processes in the foliage layer are accurately simulated by equations of the radiative transfer theory.
research objective: In this paper, an algorithm is addressed on FVC retrieval, with the combination of MODIS and Huan Jing satellite (HJ), which is a newly launched constellation by China.
challenges: As the use of HJ-1 data may increase error in data acquisition and successive operations would cause error in estimating parameter S, a Logistic model of vegetation growth is incorporated to get rid of these uncertainties.
methods: In the developed model, we considered angular effect and utilized spatial and temporal information to a great extent. A vegetation growth model was introduced to constrain the uncertainty of HJ data in a temporal scale. The uncertainty of using this algorithm was assessed by error propagation theory and field experiments.
dataset: MODIS and HJ surface reflectance products provide data supply for the algorithm and play cooperative roles.
findings: Retrieved FVC became more reasonable after consideration of the correlation among time series observations and the introduction of more observational data.

background: Fractional vegetation cover (FVC) is one of the most important criteria for surface vegetation status. This criterion corresponds to the complement of gap fraction unity at the nadir direction and accounts for the amount of horizontal vegetation distribution.
research objective: This study aims to directly validate the accuracy of FVC products over crops at coarse resolutions (1 km) by employing field measurements and high-resolution data.
challenges: However, interpolation algorithms are difficult to apply in vegetation that exhibits nonlinear and rapid changes. Image edge distortion must be corrected before FVC can be further extracted. The perspective effect and image edge distortion caused a systematic error of up to 0.03 in the estimated FVC.
methods: In this study, we used fractional vegetation cover (FVC) to validate a coarse-resolution product via an upscaling strategy. The ground-measured and airborne FVC data employed in this study were acquired during the HiWATER project. The GEOV1 FVC coarse-resolution product was validated through observations obtained during a crop-growing cycle. GEOV1 FVC was processed by temporal interpolation and compared directly with aggregated FVC throughout the growing season. FVC ground measurements were collected via digital photography from May 24 to September 14, 2012. Digital cameras were used to measure typical vegetation (e.g., cropland or orchard) FVC according to the proposed photography guidelines. The FVC of each sampling plot was computed using nine images for measurement. FVC was measured along two diagonals across the sampling plot, which was measured once for the overlapping section at the cross point of the two diagonals.
dataset: The ground-measured and airborne FVC data employed in this study were acquired during the HiWATER project. The GEOV1 FVC coarse-resolution product was derived from SPOT/VEGETATION sensors with a 10-day temporal sampling and approximately 1 km spatial sampling. Observational data included ground-based FVC measurements, radiance images from ASTER and CASI, GEOV1 FVC products, and several ancillary data such as Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) aerosol data, aerosol optical thickness measured with a sun photometer, and solar-target observational geometry data. A total of 22 sampling plots were distributed throughout the area; among these, 16 plots were located in cornfields.
findings: GEOV1 FVC was generally overestimated for crops in the study area compared with our estimates. The estimated FVC was examined step by step to ensure reliable validation. GEOV1 values were found to be overestimated FVC during our validation.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather multiscale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of hierarchically nested scales in the HiWATER experiment, which involved a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This setup aimed to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by arranging instruments in a sparse network around an oasis, including various landscapes such as sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered in the estimation of Fractional Vegetation Cover (FVC) using remote sensing data, and how was it addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge in estimating FVC using remote sensing data is the error introduced by the use of HJ-1 data, which affects data acquisition and parameter estimation. This was addressed by incorporating a Logistic model of vegetation growth to reduce uncertainties, and using error propagation theory along with field experiments to assess the uncertainty of the developed algorithm.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used for validating coarse-resolution FVC products over agricultural areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for validating coarse-resolution FVC products is the ground-measured and airborne FVC data collected during the HiWATER project. This dataset included ground-based FVC measurements, radiance images from ASTER and CASI, and GEOV1 FVC products, which were all compared to ensure reliable validation of the FVC estimates over crops.

Definition.Question: How is the concept of 'multi-scale observations' applied in eco-hydrological experiments like HiWATER?
Definition.Answer: Multi-scale observations in eco-hydrological experiments like HiWATER involve collecting data at various spatial and temporal scales to capture the complexity of eco-hydrological processes. This approach uses a combination of ground-based measurements, such as eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing technologies, like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, to provide a comprehensive dataset that can be used to study both small-scale processes and larger-scale interactions across different ecosystems.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in challenges faced by the HiWATER experiment's multiscale observations and the use of HJ-1 data in estimating FVC?
Comparison.Answer: Both face challenges related to data acquisition errors and uncertainties. The HiWATER experiment addresses the challenge of multiscale observations with a network of instruments to capture varied eco-hydrological processes, while the HJ-1 data faces challenges with data acquisition errors that are mitigated by a logistic model of vegetation growth. Both approaches aim to improve data accuracy and reliability.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological considerations are necessary to reduce systematic errors in FVC estimation when dealing with rapidly changing vegetation and image edge distortion?
Interpretation.Answer: To reduce systematic errors in FVC estimation, especially in rapidly changing vegetation, it is necessary to address image edge distortion and perspective effects. Implementing interpolation algorithms that can accommodate nonlinear vegetation changes and correcting image distortions are essential steps. Additionally, employing an upscaling strategy and utilizing temporal interpolation of coarse-resolution products can help in achieving more accurate FVC estimates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are multiscale observations challenging to obtain in eco-hydrological studies, and how has this impacted progress in the field?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The availability of multiscale observations is limited, which hinders progress in eco-hydrological studies. This challenge is addressed by using instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data, as seen in experiments like HiWATER.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the overestimation of FVC in certain products, and what methods can be employed to validate these products accurately?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Systematic errors such as perspective effects and image edge distortion can cause overestimation of FVC. To validate FVC products accurately, methods like temporal interpolation, comparison with aggregated FVC, and ground measurements using digital photography can be employed, as demonstrated in studies validating GEOV1 FVC products.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data accuracy when integrating multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiscale observations can improve data accuracy by offering comprehensive coverage of eco-hydrological processes, as demonstrated by the use of hierarchically nested scales and multiple sensor types. This approach helps capture diverse data types and scales, addressing the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations and enhancing the understanding of eco-hydrological processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using coarse-resolution products for validating FVC data in agricultural landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using coarse-resolution products for validating FVC data in agricultural landscapes can result in overestimation of FVC values, as indicated by validation results comparing GEOV1 FVC products with ground measurements. This discrepancy suggests the need for careful assessment and step-by-step validation to ensure accurate representation of FVC in such areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of employing high-resolution and multisource remote sensing data for estimating Fractional Vegetation Cover (FVC)?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of employing high-resolution and multisource remote sensing data for estimating FVC is to improve the accuracy and temporal resolution of FVC products. This approach helps to mitigate the influence of low-resolution data heterogeneity and provides a more detailed representation of vegetation dynamics, which is critical for applications in climate and weather forecasting models, agriculture, and environmental management.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in synthesizing a multiscale eco-hydrological dataset from various remote sensing instruments and ground measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The synthesis involves arranging instruments in hierarchically nested scales to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. This includes a sparse network for oasis-desert interaction, a superstation in the oasis, EC towers, AMSs in different landscapes, and intensive observations at the irrigation district scale. Additionally, 12 airborne remote sensing missions using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, thermal imager, and microwave radiometer were conducted, with careful quality control throughout sensor calibration, data collection, and processing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are uncertainties in satellite data acquisition addressed when developing algorithms for fractional vegetation cover retrieval?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Uncertainties are addressed by incorporating a Logistic model of vegetation growth to mitigate errors associated with HJ-1 data. The developed model considers angular effects and utilizes spatial and temporal information extensively, with the uncertainty assessed through error propagation theory and field experiments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to validate the accuracy of coarse-resolution FVC products using field measurements and high-resolution data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The validation procedure involves using an upscaling strategy with ground-measured and airborne FVC data. Ground measurements are collected via digital photography, and the coarse-resolution GEOV1 FVC product is validated through temporal interpolation and direct comparison with aggregated FVC data during the growing season. The process includes step-by-step examination of estimated FVC to ensure reliable validation.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the integration of multi-source remote sensing data for improving the accuracy of Fractional Vegetation Cover (FVC) estimation?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multi-source remote sensing data for improving FVC estimation is enabled by utilizing data from Terra/MODIS, Aqua/MODIS, and domestic satellites like FY3A/MERSI and FY3B/MERSI. This involves constructing a spatial resolution of 1km and a temporal resolution of 5 days, and using conversion coefficients calculated for different vegetation regions and land types. Additionally, the use of high-resolution data helps in directly obtaining vegetation cover proportions and mitigating the heterogeneity impact of low-resolution data.

Enablement.Question: What strategies are employed to ensure the reliability and accuracy of fractional vegetation cover (FVC) datasets when validating them against ground measurements and high-resolution data?
Enablement.Answer: To ensure reliability and accuracy of FVC datasets, strategies include direct validation using field measurements and high-resolution data, as seen in the HiWATER project. Ground-based FVC measurements are compared with coarse-resolution products via an upscaling strategy, involving temporal interpolation of GEOV1 FVC products. Digital photography is used for ground measurements, and systematic errors such as perspective effect and image edge distortion are corrected. The estimated FVC is examined step by step to ensure reliable validation.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multi-source remote sensing data improve the estimation accuracy and temporal resolution of fractional vegetation cover (FVC) datasets?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of multi-source remote sensing data, such as Terra/MODIS, Aqua/MODIS, and domestic satellites like FY3A/MERSI and FY3B/MERSI, allows for the construction of a dataset with a spatial resolution of 1 km and a temporal resolution of 5 days. This integration helps in obtaining a richer data set that mitigates the impact of data heterogeneity and improves the estimation accuracy of FVC parameters.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in ensuring the accuracy of FVC products when using interpolation algorithms in environments with nonlinear and rapidly changing vegetation?
Expectation.Answer: Interpolation algorithms may face challenges in accurately estimating FVC in areas with nonlinear and rapid vegetation changes due to perspective effects and image edge distortions. These issues can introduce systematic errors in estimated FVC, making it difficult to apply such algorithms effectively without proper corrections.

Judgmental.Question: What are the major challenges faced in ensuring the accuracy and consistency of Fractional Vegetation Cover (FVC) datasets, and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Major challenges include the difficulty of applying interpolation algorithms in rapidly changing vegetation and correcting image edge distortion, which can introduce systematic errors. These challenges may be addressed by employing models that incorporate temporal and spatial information, such as vegetation growth models, and by using ground-measured data for validation to improve the accuracy and consistency of FVC datasets.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can the integration of multiple remote sensing sources improve the estimation of vegetation parameters, and what potential limitations could arise from this approach?
Judgmental.Answer: Integration of multiple remote sensing sources, such as combining MODIS with other satellite data like HJ, can improve the estimation of vegetation parameters by providing a more comprehensive dataset with various spatial and temporal resolutions. However, potential limitations include increased errors in data acquisition and the complexities of processing and integrating data from different sources, which may require sophisticated algorithms to manage uncertainties.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data from different satellite sources are combined to improve the accuracy of vegetation cover estimates.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection approach involves using multiple satellite sources like Terra/MODIS, Aqua/MODIS, and FY3A/MERSI to construct a 1km spatial resolution dataset. Different vegetation zones and land types are categorized to calculate conversion coefficients between vegetation indices and Fractional Vegetation Cover (FVC). This multi-source integration helps in achieving higher estimation accuracy and temporal resolution.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when using diverse observational data to monitor eco-hydrological processes at different scales.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges include the lack of availability of multiscale observations, which can hinder progress. To address this, a hierarchically nested scale instrumentation approach is used, incorporating eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing tools like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, ensuring comprehensive data collection across different scales.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the data collection techniques used to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data in eco-hydrological studies related to oasis-desert interactions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques include the deployment of instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, flux observation matrices with eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, an eco-hydrological sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, L-band microwave radiometer, and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges and solutions involved in collecting and validating fractional vegetation cover (FVC) data over heterogeneous landscapes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the difficulty of applying interpolation algorithms for nonlinear and rapid vegetation changes, image edge distortion causing systematic errors, and the overestimation of FVC in certain products. Solutions involve employing a vegetation growth model to reduce data uncertainties, using error propagation theory and field experiments for validation, and an upscaling strategy with ground-measured and airborne FVC data to validate coarse-resolution products.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets and their sources for studying fractional vegetation cover (FVC) and related biophysical parameters, and explain their roles in eco-hydrological research.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include MODIS and Huan Jing satellite surface reflectance products, ground-measured and airborne FVC data from the HiWATER project, and GEOV1 FVC coarse-resolution products derived from SPOT/VEGETATION sensors. These datasets are used to improve FVC retrieval accuracy, validate coarse-resolution products, and analyze vegetation dynamics and eco-hydrological processes.
